Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract:

CAREER: Nonlinear Processing of Light Transport Data for Realistic Computer Imagery

PI: Rui Wang

Realistic computer graphics involving very large image datasets, such as lightfields, precomputed light transport, time-lapse video, measured material database, has become an increasingly important and interesting topic in recent years. While rendering systems can exploit these data to achieve greatly improved performance and visual fidelity, such datasets also present significant challenges for efficient processing, not only because of their large scale and high dimensionality, but more importantly, because of their intrinsic nonlinear structures. That is, the data naturally contain very high frequency, rapidly changing information that cannot be adequately represented using linear processing models that prevail elsewhere in computer graphics.

This project develops nonlinear processing methods for large-scale, multidimensional light transport data. These nonlinear methods adaptively select the best solutions for representation driven by the data?s intrinsic nonlinear structure, thereby significantly improving the sampling, compression, reduction, and reconstruction of such data. The project involves three steps of research. The first step collects light transport data from both simulated and measured sources, and derives a novel sampling strategy by using data-driven analysis. In the second step, the PI investigates several new methods for nonlinearly reducing and approximating light transport data into compact representations. These methods include nonlinear basis projection, clustered piecewise constant approximation, and augmented dimensionality reduction. The third step develops efficient computational methods using the compressed data representation for fast reconstruction and real-time visualization. These methods are naturally amenable to acceleration on modern graphics hardware. The resulting new approaches from this research can leverage broader applications in other fields that involve similar types of image datasets, such as geosciences, medical imaging, and forensic analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Realistic image synthesis by using large datasets, such as captured photographs, pre-computed renderings, time-lapse videos, measured material database, has been a central area of research in computer graphics in recent years. Applications span many science and engineering disciplines, including architectural and industrial design, prototyping, simulation, virtual reality, digital preservation, e-commerce, and education. While computer graphics systems can exploit large image datasets to achieve greatly improved rendering performance and visual fidelity, such datasets also present significant challenges for efficient processing, not only because of their large scale and high dimensionality, but more importantly, because of their intrinsic nonlinear structures. That is, the data naturally contain very high frequency, rapidly changing information that cannot be adequately models using traditional approaches.

 

In this CAREER project, the PI has investigated novel, nonlinear processing methods for realistic image synthesis, driven by large-scale, multidimensional image data. These methods adaptively select the best representations and computation models, driven by data’s intrinsic nonlinear structure, thereby significantly improving the sampling, compression, reduction, and reconstruction of such data. The PI’s research resulted in a total of 21 publications that appeared at top-tier journals (e.g. ACM Transactions on Graphics and Computer Graphics Forum) and conferences (e.g. SIGGRAPH and Eurographics). Some representative topics of these publications include: fast and realistic lighting simulation (including indirect lighting and global illumination) by leveraging precomputed image data and graphics processing units (GPUs); interactive rendering of photographic (such as depth-of-field) effects; realistic rendering of dynamic hair models; stochastic point sampling with applications in rendering, modeling, texture synthesis; and extensions of the work to other domains such as non-photorealistic rendering, 3D modeling and simulation.


In terms of education, broader impact and outreach: in addition to continuing to expand the CS curriculum and mentoring graduate and undergraduate students, for the past several years the PI has served as undergraduate event director, and regularly offered a series of events called 'Wearable Electronics’ workshops. These workshops combine programming with craft, art, electronics, and design, and inspire students to apply the knowledge they learned in classrooms to make projects that are physical, tangible, and beautiful. The workshops have been very successful at involving women and underrepresented participants. As the main organizer, the PI spent a considerable amount of time on the logistics, including coming up with ideas, ordering materials/supplies, prototyping, making slides, and coordinating volunteers. In addition, the PI has extended these workshops and hands-on activities to nearby colleges, such as Mount Holyoke College and Smith College, both top-tier women's colleges in the Amherst area. The details of some of these events are documented on the following website: http://umasscs.wordpress.com/wearable-electronics-night/
